com: How important is a brake flush if you haven't done it in a while?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26152131
yeah, it really is better to just replace it every 2 years or so. The colour is a better indicator than any of those trash conductivity testers. Those fancy boiling point testers only require you to hook them up to the battery, stick the probe into the reservoir then wait about a minute while it heats up a sample, but only really useful for shops that do this stuff all the time.
Colour would be a better indicator than any of those store bought testers, bad fluid looks more green than a gold colour, assuming you're using fluid with no fancy colouring. If fluid looks like spinach juice, flush that shit out asap.
>>26152171
This is also true. Wet boiling points of different fluids for reference in pic related
DOT5 is hydrophobic so any moisture that gets inside will actually pool at the bottiom of lines, which makes me wonder if there are systems that use this fluid and have a tap or valve at the lowest point to drain this water.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26152131
Brake fluid absorbs water which corrodes the fuck out of brake systems.
Ask any experienced motorcycle mechanic if you doubt that.

Before expensive ABS systems it regularly fucked up calipers (water is heavier than brake jooce so sufficient unmixed excess sinks) but those were cheap to rebuild if the pistons were not corroded.

In 2022 systems with ABS are more complex with more complex. expensive components. If you trade in your machine you can stick the next owner with the repair bill but if not, price ABS system parts for your bike. Brake fluid is cheap but new parts cost considerably more and if you're not a mechanic you get to pay one.

https://www.kawasakininja1000.com/threads/1-900-for-replacing-abs-unit-in-sf.24354/

I wrench so not my problem and mechanics like money too.

name: Anonymous
com:
GM unveiled a huge new lineup of full-sizer cars for 1971. The Cadillac versions swelled to a 130" wheelbase and 5,000 pound curb weight. Topping the line was the Sixty Special, riding a 133" wheelbase, the largest mass production American car ever built. Convertible models did not return, leaving Cadillac soft tops exclusively to the Eldorado until getting the axe in 1975 as part of a general Detroit phase-out of convertibles. Standard drivetrain was the 472 V8, now detuned to be compatible with emissions hardware. Styling changes over six model years were mostly detail and concerned changes to the grille and the adoption of now legalized square headlight on '76 models. For 1974 the addition of 5 mph bumpers and catalytic converters added still more curb weight. Due to this added bulk the Eldorado's 500 cid V8 was made standard in C and D-body Cadillacs.

But size had clearly gotten out of hand, and soon after the new full-sizers arrived in showrooms during fall 1970, GM was making plans for a downsized successor, and the OPEC embargo in late 1973-early '74 accelerated the project.

>>26149327
mechanical engineer here:
The torque numbers are just CYA shit. We basically just torque it till it feel right, figure out what that number is, and if it passes the test without coming loose we say "alright, put it in the manual". It's just so limp wrists don't under-tighten it and have it rattle loose or ugga dugga cavemen don't impact the shit out of it and blame the manufacturer when they break the head off the bolt. Torque-to-yield bolts are a little different and a little more precise, but for normal fasteners a good feel for a tight bolt is honestly better than a torque spec as any variance in the condition of the bolt threads (rust, general wear, wayward oil/lubricant, etc) will affect the ideal torque.

If you have to ask these questions, that engine is too complicated for you
Just Ls swap it

Verification not required

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26151891
>>Why is the K24 engine used so commonly for projects and engine changes? Why is it good?
Because there are millions of them on the road and tons of them in the junk yard for you to pull
>>How is it possible to tune it to generate a lot more power than it has by default?
This really depends on what you wanna do with it. You can do naturally aspirated ones that make 300whp easily
>>How much of the stock engine's components are changed to handle the higher horsepower and torque?
IIRC its mostly valves, springs, retainers, cams, intakes, exhausts. The engines are very robust on their own, there isn't a need for much else.
>>Does Honda make it easy to exchange engines between their cars or is the community just that dedicated to making these engine swaps?
Honda basically put it into virtually every one of their cars at one point. The aftermarket is huge. After B-series engines started to get old it became readily available to swap up into K-series.
>>Is this the reason old civics are so valuable?
Japanese cars in general are more valuable than American ones purely because japanese ones are miles more reliable.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26151891
k24's are good for projects because they're cheaper than b-series while being 2.4l instead of 1.8(or 2.0) and having a better block design (split block vs girdle)

it's easy to get a moderate power increase but 300+ like the other guy said requires high compression, ITB's and exotic fuel. you can expect more in the 230-40whp range for mildly built n/a, still a lot of fun though. i have loads of fun with a 177hp b18c 240 would be a blast

it's more the community, putting k's into older hondas requires custom mounts because k series drivetrains are flipped 180 degrees from B D and H series (transmission on opposite side, intake/exhaust position flipped too), it's a common enough swap that the mounts and shifter conversion parts are relatively cheap on ebay though

the reason old civics are so valuable is because they're dope, theres still a thriving aftermarket and they are light, great suspension design, easy to work on, with high-revving, engaging engines that make them feel much faster than they actually are

com:
Why don't electric cars have the same combination of speed, acceleration, and endurance that ICE cars and diesel cars do?

Electric cars can accelerate faster, but if they do so their range decreases precipitiously. Likewise, they cannot drive fast speeds for long distances because driving fast drains their batteries. This is much more of a problem for them than either ICE cars or diesel cars.

Tesla owners like to tout their acceleration but they don't have endurance at speed, and electric cars may NEVER have this.

Pic related, Volkswagen's old TDI was a king among engines.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26150971
Those kinds of systems are yeah.

They had electric busses for a while that used a similar trolley charger style system. When the bus parked in this precise spot this fancy robot arm would come out and hook up to the charger and then the arm would retract when the bus needed to get going again.
Eventually they figured out that with all the maintenance the arm and the charger needed, and how precisely it needed to be stopped, it would be cheaper to just rip up the concrete and put inductive charging underneath.

I suspect that's what's going to be the ultimate solution. Inductive charging under the road in areas where trucks might need to take on or offload power, and inductive chargers at spots vehicles will sit. Like an Airport taxi queue, or a fast food drive through. The install costs more money, but after that its all solid state, no moving parts for the charger or the vehicle.

name: Anonymous
com:
The redoubtable Kenosha, Wisconsin-based Nash introduced their new postwar models for 1949. The Airflyte was one of the more radical designs of the era, replacing the company's entirely conventional-looking 1941-48 models with a large, bulbous new vehicle. Emphasis was on safety and comfort, sporting a padded "safety" dashboard sporting a large instrument pod that combined all gauges in one unit, and a huge interior with fold-down rear seats that could be made into a bed (as such these Nashes were said to be the dread of every teenage daughter's parents). Performance was not an emphasis, with Nash's 172 cid I6, making 112 hp at the wheels, being the only drivetrain offered. Nash also boasted of the car's excellent fuel economy, good for up to 30 mpg, and long range due to the 20 gallon fuel tank (claimed range was up to 500 miles). They had offered I8s in the past but they didn't return after civilian car production resumed in late 1945. Only a sedan and coupe were offered, in either base 600 or high trim Ambassador models.

The bulbous 49-51 Nash styling, also shared by the contemporary Lincoln Cosmopolitan, was a period fad that became dated quickly and disappeared with the more blocky 1952 models.

com: It seems to me that it should be pretty easy to put electric motors and a small battery pack on the back of an FWD car to make it an awd with very little added weight. Or pop the rear driveshaft out of a Subaru and bolt an electric motor to the rear differential. Such a thing would increase power and efficiency and in the first example add utility to the old FWD cars. Then it would be a matter of matching the throttle input front and rear, and using either Regen to top off the battery and or have a high voltage alternator added to the engine bay. This could be a good business too- converting FWD crossovers into hybrid 4x4s. Should cost less than alot of performance mods that people currently do.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26149002
I've also thought about this. It's taking existing cars and making them faster and more ecofriendly to drive, and it's certainly going to be less expensive and more ecologically friendly than forcing people to replace their old cars with new battery-powered models. This is why it will not catch on-- it makes too much sense.

This seems like a good application for wheel hub motors. I suspect that the task of getting good, seemless integration between existing internal combustion system and the EV system will be the most challenging aspect.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26149045

Especially since people spend $10k on engine mods that blow up the engine and reduce MPG for 100Hp gains. A hybrid setup would add reliability. The problem with hub motors is that in order ro get torque they need substantial gear reduction or they need to be huge, heavy and rpm limited. This limits top speed and adds unsprung weight. Plus having 4 Gauge 100V wires bouncing around in salt and dirt isnt exactly safe and reliable. So this would work best for crossovers that had an awd option, or were built with AWD so that you can bolt an e-drive rear end and keep that isolated from the elements
